description: From Middle English wisshen, wischen, wüschen, from Old English wȳsċan (“to wish”), from Proto-West Germanic *wunskijan, from Proto-Germanic *wunskijaną (“to wish”), from Proto-Indo-European *wenh₁- (“to wish, love”).

Cognate with Scots wis (“to wish”), Saterland Frisian wonskje (“to wish”), West Frisian winskje (“to wish”), Dutch wensen (“to wish”), German wünschen (“to wish”), Danish ønske (“to wish”), Icelandic æskja, óska (“to wish”), Latin Venus, veneror (“venerate, honour, love”).

entries.meaning: A desire, hope, or longing for something or for something to happen.
An expression of such a desire, often connected with ideas of magic and supernatural power.
The thing desired or longed for.
examples: My dearest wish is to see them happily married.

verbs.description: wish (third-person singular simple present wishes, present participle wishing, simple past and past participle wished)

examples: I'll come tomorrow, if you wish it.

entries.meaning: (transitive, now rare) To hope (+ object clause with may or in present subjunctive).
examples: She hears that Miss Bigg is to be married in a fortnight. I wish it may be so.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, followed by for) To hope (for a particular outcome), even if that outcome is unlikely to occur or cannot occur.
examples: This is as good an argument as an antiquary could wish for.

entries.meaning: (ditransitive) To bestow (a thought or gesture) towards (someone or something).
examples: We wish you a Merry Christmas.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, followed by to and an infinitive) To request or desire to do an activity.
(transitive) To recommend; to seek confidence or favour on behalf of.
examples: I was wished to your worship by a gentleman.
